Canada and the worldGlobal Affairs CanadaEmbassy of Canada to Ireland and COVID-19: Frequently asked questionsen2020-04-09https://www.international.gc.ca/country-pays/ireland-irlande/covid-19.aspx?lang=eng On this page; If I am a Canadian citizen, should I leave Ireland and return to Canada because of the COVID-19 pandemic?; If I am a Canadian citizen living in Ireland and my long stay visa or my residency permit will expire in the coming weeks, do I have to leave Ireland and return to Canada?; If I am Canadian and I am leaving Ireland, do I have to self-isolate when I get back to Canada?; If I am a Canadian citizen, can I travel to Ireland from Canada?; If I am a Canadian citizen, will the Embassy of Canada to Ireland assist me to find flight information and buy or change an airline ticket to return to Canada?; Can I travel to Canada if I have symptoms of COVID-19?; What is the status of flights to Canada from Ireland?; Are there any restrictions on my ability to go to the airport to get my flight back to Canada?; If I am a Canadian citizen, can I travel in Ireland while waiting for my flight back to Canada?; If I am a Canadian citizen in Ireland, do I have to follow the same confinement measures as Irish citizens?; What is the state of public transit in Ireland, other than international airlines?; If commercial flights stop, will I be repatriated?; Under what conditions can I apply for an individual reimbursable loan of $5000, as announced by the federal government?; Immigration queries; Regular consular services suspendedCanadian citizens who live, travel or are planning to travel in Ireland, please register yourselves as Canadian citizens abroad to receive updates from the Embassy. Also please note that you are responsible for your personal security abroad, and are subject to local health regulations in the country while you are there.Main Covid-19 contentNoEmbassy of Canada to Ireland and COVID-19: Frequently asked questions

N/AParks Canada AgencyThings to do - Halifax Citadel National Historic Siteen2020-04-06https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/lhn-nhs/ns/halifax/activThings to doStaff at the Halifax Citadel have crafted many ways to transport you back in time to the life of a Victorian era soldier. Join a guided tour or explore the various sites within the fort on your own. Watch the noon firing of the gun, listen to the stirring sounds of the bagpipes, or join a signature experience and become part of the 78th Highlanders for the day. Educators can also join in an engaging Canadian history program.Contains Covid AlertYesThings to do - Halifax Citadel National Historic Site

Canada and the worldGlobal Affairs CanadaThe Canada Fund for Local Initiatives - Lesotho, Madagascar, Mauritius, Namibia, South Africaen2020-04-21https://www.international.gc.ca/world-monde/funding-financement/cfli-fcil/2020/south_africa-afrique_du_sud.aspx?lang=engProgram Description ; How to apply; General Information; Organizations eligible to apply for CFLI funding ; Thematic priorities ; COVID-19 Crisis ; Gender-based analysis  ; Eligible costsThe CFLI is a program designed to support small-scale, high-impact projects in developing countries that align with Global Affairs Canada’s thematic priority areas for engagement. The program is directed at projects conceived and designed predominantly by local partners. Projects are selected and approved by the relevant Canadian embassy or high commission. The CFLI also serves to support positive bilateral relations between Canada and recipient countries and their civil societies by deepening contacts and supporting local endeavours.Main Covid-19 contentYesThe Canada Fund for Local Initiatives - Lesotho, Madagascar, Mauritius, Namibia, South Africa

N/AParks Canada AgencyKejimkujik National Park and National Historic Siteen2020-03-27https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/ns/kejimkujikThere are many sides to Kejimkujik National Park and National Historic Site. Inland, old growth hemlock, sugar maple and yellow aspen trees border warm-water lakes with quartzite shores. Kejimkujik Seaside, a separate landscape, juxtaposes with colourful barrens, granite cobbles and white-sand beaches. The land also tells the tale of the Mi’kmaw, carved in stone and illuminated through story and legend. Paddle the waters, hike the trails and discover the rich diversity of Kejimkujik.Contains Covid AlertNoKejimkujik National Park and National Historic Site

N/AParks Canada AgencyVisitor safety - Quttinirpaaq National Parken2020-03-27https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/nu/quttinirpaaq/securite-safetyVisitor safetyOn Ellesmere Island, less than 800 kilometres (500 miles) from the North Pole, Quttinirpaaq is the world’s northernmost national park. If heading into the park, it is essential to be self-sufficient and experienced. Individual travellers are welcome, though most visitors arrive with an outfitter for one or two weeks of outdoor activities like hiking, skiing, mountain climbing or traversing ice caps and glaciers.Contains Covid AlertYesVisitor safety - Quttinirpaaq National Park

N/AParks Canada AgencyThings to do - Port-Royal National Historic Siteen2020-04-02https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/lhn-nhs/ns/portroyal/activThings to doStep into the unique environment of a reconstructed early 17th century French colony, interacting with costumed interpreters who answer questions and point out details about construction techniques and the daily lives and skills of the Habitation’s residents. In this unique place carved out of the wilderness, learn about the beginnings of European colonization and settlement, and the French settlers’ amiable, important relationship with the Mi'kmaq people.Contains Covid AlertNoThings to do - Port-Royal National Historic Site

N/AParks Canada AgencyWrecks of HMS Erebus and HMS Terror National Historic Siteen2020-03-20https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/lhn-nhs/nu/epaveswrecksIn 1845, explorer Sir John Franklin set sail from England with two ships, HMS Erebus and HMS Terror, in search of a Northwest Passage across what is now Canada's Arctic. The ships and crews vanished, prompting a massive search that continues to this day. A breakthrough was made in September 2014 when an expedition led by Parks Canada discovered the wreck of HMS Erebus. This discovery lead to the creation of the Wrecks of HMS Erebus and HMS Terror National Historic Site of Canada.Contains Covid AlertNoWrecks of HMS Erebus and HMS Terror National Historic Site

If so, what type of expense is included and to whom do these apply?; Question 9: Does the guidance set a time limit for eligibility of expenditures related to the repatriation of project staff and their dependants, volunteers, interns and students?; Question 10: Are safety kits and safety equipment eligible costs?; Question 11: Once repatriated, if volunteers are able to resume their contribution to the project, will the deemed daily value already established for the purpose of the recipient organization’s cost share continue to count as their in-kind contribution?; Question 12: Once repatriated, if volunteers are able to resume their contributions to the project, will an overhead allowance of 12% of a deemed $200 per day value continue to be paid to the recipient organization?; Question 13: By when must recipient organizations communicate with their respective GAC project officer about their reassessment of the project’s feasibility?; Question 14: What happens if project activities are not resumed within the 30-working-day period and the Canadian partner must lay off staff in a country that legally requires a certain length of time between the issuance of a layoff notice and the end of employment?; Question 15: Is the flexibility offered through the guidance only applicable to COVID-19-crisis-related costs?; Question 16: What flexibility can be offered without amending the contribution agreement?; Question 17: Can a recipient organization that currently has an operational contribution agreement with GAC modify certain project activities to address some of the immediate COVID-19 issues in the country of their project?; Question 18: What is a minimum amount of activity required to justify continued payment of salaries?; Question 19: Can Can recipient organizations claim costs as per the guidance as well as through other government-announced measures, if applicable?; Environment and natural resourcesEnvironment and Climate Change CanadaVaseux Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuaryen2020-03-27https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/migratory-bird-sanctuaries/locations/vaseux-lake.htmlNotice; Importance of the sanctuary: migratory birds and other wildlife; Landscape; Map of the area; Planning your visit; Key facts about Vaseux Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary; Related links; Contact informationVaseux Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary (MBS) is situated 5 km south of Okanagan Falls on Highway 97 in the Okanagan Valley of southern British Columbia. Vaseux Lake is in the Osoyoos-Arid Biotic Area, which is a northern extension of the Great Basin Desert.The MBS was originally established to provide protection to Trumpeter Swans. Canada Geese use the site extensively and nest in numbers exceeding 200 on Hatfield Island.Contains Covid AlertGeneral PublicNoVaseux Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary

Use this form to submit corrections or comments on this row in the inventory. Comments will be reviewed by DTO

Web Content Inventory Instructions

The COVID-19 Web content inventory tool relies on data from two sources:

  • Canada.ca search results
  • AEM web crawl

We aim to update the tool daily.

You can use the tool to validate and improve metadata. You can also identify:

  • what COVID-19 content exists for a particular theme or department
  • duplication or overlap
  • out-of-date materials

Tool use examples

These examples show specific uses for validation of content and updates to metadata.

E.g. The Benefits theme lead wants to ensure there are no out-dated alerts

  • On the left side of the page, select Benefits in the theme drop down
  • Select “alerts” for content type
  • Click “Filter” button to show results
  • Click and hold the URL column header and reposition it to the left of the page title
  • Select each page URL to verify that the alerts are still accurate

E.g. The Department of Finance wants to ensure their COVID-19 pages are following the metadata guidance for titles

  • On the left side of the page, select Department of Finance in the departments list
  • Click the filter button to show results
  • Click and hold the TITLE column and move it to the right of the Department column
  • A review of results shows COVID appears in some cases, but not all
  • Click the “Excel” button towards the top of the page to download a spreadsheet of these results
  • Use the spreadsheet to provide clear instructions to the department content manager

Considerations

  • The tool is available in English and French
  • The left side of the page provides the main site filters – theme, department and four types of content:
  • Main COVID-19 content returns pages that include substantive information on health, economics, restrictions, etc. Generally, pages accessible from Canada.ca/covid19 are “main COVID-19” content.
  • Alerts returns pages that include an visual and textual alert, with some content related to COVID-19, usually in relation to a service interruption.
  • Links returns pages that include a link to a page with COVID-19 content
  • News returns 5 types of news releases and announcements, including:
    • backgrounders
    • media advisories
    • news releases
    • speeches
    • statements
  • The columns can be rearranged by clicking, holding and dragging them to the position you want The toggles at the top of the page give you additional control over what you see Use the Filter reset button if your results are not what you expected

Generate an Excel report for internal use

To generate an Excel report:

  • Use the filter tool, to get the results you want,
  • click the Excel button.
  • Use the comments column in the Excel report to indicate changes or questions for your web team, program area or communications team

This may be useful for:

  • corrections
  • removal or archiving of pages
  • adding new pages to your cluster

Submit comments to the Digital Transformation Office (DTO)

To submit comments about a specific page to the DTO, click the Submit button in the Comments column for that page in the inventory tool. Comments are sent to: dto.btn@tbs-sct.gc.ca

Comments will help us to complete a QA on the tool. Right now we see this tool as an alpha release, there are improvements and corrections required.
